conclusion: Determine the refractive index of the glass column using Snell's Law.
The glass column has a quarter circle cross-section with radius R.
The light enters at point P on the arc and travels parallel to line AC.
The distance from P to the line AC is (sqrt(3)R)/2.
The light exits at point M on line BC, where MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3.
The angle of incidence i at point P is the angle between the incoming light and the normal to the surface at P.
The angle of refraction r is the angle between the refracted light and the normal to the surface at P.
Snell's Law states: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r).
n1 is the refractive index of air (approximately 1), and n2 is the refractive index of the glass.
The angle i is the angle between the radius at P and the horizontal line.
Since P is on the arc, the radius at P makes an angle of 30 degrees with the horizontal.
The angle of refraction r is such that the light travels directly to M.
Since MC = (sqrt(3)R)/3, the angle r is 30 degrees.
Using Snell's Law: sin(60 degrees) = n2 sin(30 degrees).
sin(60 degrees) = sqrt(3)/2 and sin(30 degrees) = 1/2.
Multiply both sides by 2: sqrt(3) = n2.
The refractive index of the glass column is sqrt(3).
